subject: Re: ClassNotFoundException
msgSnippet: OK, well mt test project is the HSC package, and i ve included that in the classpath (vaj ide project_resources HSC). However none of the classes are found! Is
messageBody:
OK, well mt test project is the HSC package, and i've included that
in the classpath (vaj\ide\project_resources\HSC).

However none of the classes are found!
Is this a VAJ3.5 bug or am I really stupid?!?!

I've been running from the main method of testrunner, since I cant
get it to work any other way, but I still have a problem using the
Class.forName("className") method call...



--- In junit@y..., "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@t...> wrote:
> Generally, they _will_ be empty. The magic here is that by
including the
> project directory in the workspace classpath you automagically gets
the
> project included as well.
>
> Also, I don't run tests with JUnit class files or the JUnit jar. I
import
> the source into VAJ, include the project into the workspace
classpath
> (through one of the two ways already mentioned), write the .ini and
away we
> go.
>
> What most folks don't know is that you don't have to add any class
files to
> the file system at all for VAJ tools to work. As long as the class
the tool
> is referencing is in the workspace classpath VAJ will find it.
This has
> several obvious advantages (real time recompilation, powerful
debugging
> support, etc.) and some disadvantages (needs to be compiled every
time, so
> start up is somewhat slower, but noticeable only if you have a low
> memory/resources machine, etc.).
>
> -Jason
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: messy_head_2001@y... [mailto:messy_head_2001@y...]
> > Sent: Thursday, August 23, 2001 9:51 AM
> > To: junit@y...
> > Subject: [junit] Re: ClassNotFoundException
> >
> >
> > I have already done the first, with no result.
> > Checking my project directory under project_resources I
> > find it is
> > empty?!
> >
> >
> > --- In junit@y..., "Jason Rogers" <jason.rogers@t...> wrote:
> > > If you are running in VAJ, just add the
> > project_resources folder
> > for all
> > > projects into your workspace classpath or dynamically load
all
> > projects into
> > > the workspace classpath. Here is a class that will run
> > JUnit like
> > this,
> > > edit your JUnit tool's default.ini to point to this class.
> > >
> > >
> > > package <your package>;
> > >
> > > import junit.<your favorite ui>.*;
> > >
> > > public class JUnitLauncher {
> > > public JUnitLauncher() {}
> > > public static void main(String args[]) {
> > > JUnitLauncher.setClassPath();
> > > TestRunner.main(args);
> > > }
> > > /**
> > > * Update the classpath to include all workspace projects.
> > > */
> > > public void setClassPath() throws IvjException {
> > >
> > > Workspace workspace = ToolEnv.connectToWorkspace();
> > > Object[] classpath = workspace.getClassPathEntries();
> > > Object[] projects = workspace.getProjects();
> > > Object[] newClasspath = new Object[classpath.length +
> > > projects.length];
> > >
> > > //add the projects to the new classpath
> > > System.arraycopy(projects, 0, newClasspath, 0,
> > projects.length);
> > >
> > > //add the original classpath to the new classpath
> > > System.arraycopy(classpath, 0, newClasspath,
> > projects.length,
> > > classpath.length);
> > >
> > > try {
> > > workspace.setClassPath(newClasspath);
> > > } catch(IvjException e) {
> > > e.printStackTrace();
> > > }
> > >
> > > }
> > > }
> > >
> > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > From: messy_head_2001@y...
[mailto:messy_head_2001@y...]
> > > > Sent: Wednesday, August 22, 2001 11:44 AM
> > > > To: junit@y...
> > > > Subject: [junit] Re: ClassNotFoundException
> > > >
> > > >
> > > > is there any way to force it to load the missing
classes?
> > > >
> > > > --- In junit@y..., "Jason Rogers"
> > <jason.rogers@t...> wrote:
> > > > > That class was probably not loaded in by your
> > class loader.
> > > > >
> > > > > > -----Original Message-----
> > > > > > From: messy_head_2001@y...
> > [mailto:messy_head_2001@y...]
> > > > > > Sent: Wednesday, August 22, 2001 9:47 AM
> > > > > > To: junit@y...
> > > > > > Subject: [junit] ClassNotFoundException
> > > > > >
> > > > > >
> > > > > > I am trying to use JUnit to test a method
> > which calls
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Class.forName("myClassName")
> > > > > >
> > > > > > however I get a ClassNotFoundException
> > from this line
> > of
> > > > > > code, which
> > > > > > works perfectly when not using JUnit.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > Any ideas??
> > > > > >
> > > > > > David.
